Article.Abstract: Bacterial antigens recognized by CD8(+) T cells in the context of MHC class I are thought to play a crucial role in protection against pathogenic intracellular bacteria. Here, we demonstrate the induction of HLA-A*0201-restricted CD8(+) T cell responses against six new high-affinity HLA-A*0201-binding CTL epitopes, encoded within an immunodominant and highly conserved antigen of Mycobacteria, the heat shock protein 65 (hsp65). One of these epitopes, Mhsp65(9(369)), is identical in a large number of pathogenic bacteria, and is recognized in a CD8-independent fashion. Mhsp65(9(369)) could be presented by either mycobacterial hsp65-pulsed target cells or BCG-infected macrophages. Interestingly, T cells specific for this epitope did not recognize the corresponding human hsp65 homologue, probably due to structural differences as revealed by modeling studies. Furthermore, in vitro proteasome digestion analyses show that, whereas the mycobacterial hsp65 epitope is efficiently generated, the human hsp65 homologue is not, thus avoiding the induction of autoreactivity. Collectively, these findings describe high-affinity HLA class I-binding epitopes that are naturally processed and are recognized efficiently by MHC class I-restricted CD8(+) T cells, providing a rational basis for the development of subunit vaccine strategies against tuberculosis and other intracellular infectious diseases.
Article.ArticleTitle: The identification of a common pathogen-specific HLA class I A*0201-restricted cytotoxic T cell epitope encoded within the heat shock protein 65.
Article.Affiliations: Microbiology and Tumorbiology Center, Karolinska Institute, Stockholm, Sweden. jehad.charo@mtc.ki.se.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Strong proliferative response to the epitope (Mhsp65(9<sub>369</sub>)), as well as to the recombinant Mhsp65 protein were detected in splenocyte cultures from mice immunized with the epitope, suggesting that the epitope (Mhsp65(9<sub>369</sub>)) is naturally processed.

Strong proliferative response to the epitope (Mhsp65(9<sub>369</sub>)), as well as to the recombinant Mhsp65 protein were detected in splenocyte cultures from mice immunized with the epitope, suggesting that the epitope (Mhsp65(9<sub>369</sub>)) is naturally processed.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Splenocytes were restimulated in vitro with the epitope.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Three specific CTL clones, generated from a CTL line directed to the epitope, killed Mhsp65 (9<sub>369</sub>) peptide pulsed targets. One of the clones responded to the epitope by producing IFN-γ (ELISPOT).

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBLs from the A*0201+ donor were stimulated by the epitope-pulsed in vitro cultured mature autologous dendritic cells. The resulting cell line was repeatedly depleted of CD4+ T cellls, resulting in the production of a CD8+ T cell line. Three more restimulations were performed.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: A CTL line produced IFN-γ in response to BCG infected cells and epitope-pulsed cells, demostrating that Mhsp65(9<sub>369</sub>) is processed and presented naturally by mycobacteria-infected human macrophages. CTL lines also lysed targets loaded with the epitope and produced TNF-α in response to the epitope. Both human and mouse proteasomes generated almost identical digestion products from an epitope containing 26-mer, indicating that processing of this epitope is similar in mouse and human.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: 20 µg of P3M.65 plasmid in PBS or BSA in PBS

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Splenocytes were restimulated in vitro with the epitope.
Splenocytes were restimulated in vitro with the epitope.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: No killing of target cells pulsed with homologous human peptide Huhsp65(9<sub>396</sub>) was detected, ruling out the possibility of inducing a cross-reactive immune response to human hsp65 peptide upon immunization with the Mhsp65(9<sub>369</sub>) epitope. The clones also did not produce IFN-γ in response to the peptide.

Clones obtained from a CTL line from mice immunized with a Mhsp65(9<sub>369</sub>) epitope from Mycobacterium tuberculosis produced IFN-γ in response to the epitope. Human CTL lines obtained by immunizing human PBMC (from A*0201+ donor) with Mhsp65(9<sub>369</sub>) epitope also produced TNF-α.
